review: Great little box!  One word:  AirPlay!  If you have an iPhone or iPad, it is worth it solely for this feature.  You can 'mirror' what is on your display, and also stream audio/video via AirPlay.I have two of these at home, one is connected to my 50 inch plasma for video/streaming.  Mostly Hulu/Netflix/YouTube.Another is in a different room connected via HDMI to my AV Receiver for audio only.  I listen to music and podcasts on this one.  Apps that support AirPlay that I have used and work (there are probably lots more than this):  Downcast, Pandora, Spotify, built in Music app, NPR News, NPR Music, TuneIn Radio, and Amazon Cloud Player.PROS:--AirPlay, AirPlay, AirPlay!--Great Netflix/Hulu interfaces--YouTube (go to "most watched" today or this week to see the latest viral videos)--1080p video looks fantastic--More content available with the latest software update (v5.3), including HBOGO, WatchESPN, and Sky News.--Draws less than 1 watt of power for the 3rd gen, rev2 model -- A1469.  This is according to an analysis done by AnandTech in March 2013--Small:  about the size of a hockey puck!  Speaking of hockey pucks, there's a great built in app for watching NHL highlights (free)!CONS:--Apple has not opened up the Apple TV platform for app development, but this is not as important with the AirPlay feature.TIPS AND TRICKS:--With the latest software update (v5.3), there are now many apps on the home screen.  You can clean this up a bit and hide the ones you are not using by going to Settings-->General-->Parental Controls.  Scroll to the bottom, and you can toggle show/hide for each app.--To move apps around on the home screen, hold down the 'select' button and then you will be able to move it to wherever you like.--To go back to the home screen at any time, hold down the 'menu' button for a second or so.--Remote control:  You can pair the Apple TV with a universal remote (go to settings to set this up).  You can also control via the 'Remote' app in Apple's App Store, or even pair it with a Bluetooth keyboard (I have not tried the latter).--The Apple TV drives both the HDMI output and optical audio output at the same time.All in all, if you have an iPad/iPhone, I would say get this and enjoy!If you don't have an iPad/iPhone, it is still one of the best streaming boxes out there -- the Netflix and Hulu interfaces are the best I have seen.
